Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2017 Programming Languages Mentoring Workshop (PLMW) at ACM SIGPLAN SPLASH Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ACM SIGPLAN Conference on Systems, Programming, Languages and Applications: Software for Humanity (SPLASH) is a conference that brings together researchers and practitioners in the intersection of programming languages and software engineering. SPLASH, formerly known an OOPSLA, has had a long history beginning in 1986. SPLASH 2017 will be held in Vancouver, Canada from October 22 -27, 2017. This year, the conference is organizing a mentoring workshop for undergraduate and graduate students. This grant supports travel and attendance at the workshop, also enabling attendance at the main conference.

The project will attract a more diverse set of undergraduates and junior graduate students to participate in the field, offer practical advice about graduate study, give a perspective on where the field is going, and help students navigate the SPLASH conference to gain as much from it as possible. The overall goal is to create the needed pipeline of trained researchers, academics with expertise in programming languages and software engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the Programming Languages Mentoring Workshop at SPLASH 2017 was to attract undergraduates and young graduate students to a research career in programming languages and software engineering. Students’ travel and registration were provided to attend the workshop and the SPLASH 2017 research conference, to become familiar with research careers in academia and industry, and to informally meet senior research mentors and young researchers from across the globe.  Specific goals included: (i) to attract a more diverse set of students to research in programming languages and software engineering, the focus of SPLASH research, (ii) to offer practical advice about graduate study, some first-hand from recent Ph.D. graduates as well as mentoring by senior scholars,  (iii) to give students an overview of where the field is going, and (iv) to help students navigate the activities at the SPLASH conference itself.   Participants were selected for factors consistent with our goals.  NSF funding was leveraged by obtaining additional donations from ACM SIGPLAN and private/industry donations. In total, thirty-four students were funded to attend the workshop.  All NSF-funded attendees were students at US colleges and universities.  In attendance were 21 undergraduates and 13 graduate students, 22 males and 12 females, including 10 students from ethnicities currently underrepresented in computing.
